title: Curating and Learning from Future Architecture

author: Ana Jeinić, Graz University of Technology

segmentation: After England's presentation, I'm going to present myself as architectural terrorist and settle architectural theorist with someone but.
Much better.
So it's Marcus has already said the I'm going to present this project for the second time here.
The architecture after the future curatorial project was submitted to the first call for ideas over the future Architecture platform and selected.
It was one of these 25 projects that were presented here in Ljubljana two years ago.
Now of course, thanks to holiday, I have the opportunity to present it from a different perspective.
Now as a material materialized project and I'm really very glad about having this this opportunity and I apologize to those.
I will of course have to explain once again like the.
Basic curatorial concept that some of you have already heared.
But for those who have not.
First, explain it once again.
So what I find very interesting is that although.
Steven and Ingrid's, and my curatorial concept were developed at the same time, more or less so.
My proposal was not.
Kind of response to theirs, but.
It appears as if it would be because the two approaches are in many ways, complementary, both in regard to the contents as well as in regards to the procedure.
So, um.
My concept is based on the hypothesis that it is very difficult or virtually impossible to be a futuristic optimist today as an architect.
Because.
I think that we live in an age that is characterized by the general crisis of the future oriented imagination and this crisis concerns in the 1st place the the political imagination.
So the the even the political left, from which we expect that.
It could somehow offer perspectives that could bring us out of the.
Kind of this capitalist present and offer us a different future.
They have deliberately renounced on devising kind of common project for the future, and there are a few reasons why why it is so.
I think the most important two reasons are that the political left has internalised.
The two kind of anti futurist discourses and the first of them is the discourse of totalitarianism and the second one is the discourse of complexity so.
This fear of being accused for being totalitarian is something that.

Inhibits the left from really proposing Aurora developing common project for the future and the second one is this idea of complexity that we are living in a complex in a society which is too complex to be consciously.
Developed particularly on the global scale, so.
There are some signs that this situation might might be changing.
At least at the level of the political theory I have the impression that the future is somehow coming back, but it has not yet become part of integral part of the progressive social movements.
They still don't talk about the future and.
As long as this situation is like it is at the moment, we cannot expect from architecture to be kind of the lost and lonely Island of Futurism.
I mean, yes, there can be of course like small.

Futuristic projects mostly focused on like invention, technological inventions, but I think that it remains on a rather superficial level and if architecture wants to regain this few dimension of the future that has somehow get lost, it cannot do it just within it's kind of.
Closed disciplinary circle.
It will have to do it together with broader social forces, but I think the first step toward overcoming this crisis is understanding it.
And this is what?
My.
Curatorial Project was about so.
Its main goal was to.
To observe and analyze and map how contemporary architectural practice has consciously or unconsciously developed different strategies to adapt to.
What we could call the post futurist cultural condition, or or countercultural condition that is shaped by the crisis of the future oriented imagination.
I think that there are different design strategies which, when kind of deeply analyzed.
Uh.
Can can be seen as as a ways of responding to this crisis, or internalising it.
And somehow all of these different strategies either eliminate or distort the dimension of the future, which is inherent to architectural project.
Actually, every architectural project is a project of the future by its very nature's so.
I think it must be kind of very interesting phenomenon to see how the discipline which is inherently futuristic has adapted to a non futuristic cultural condition.
And so I.
Tried to.
Observe and define these strategies in order to make such a mapping.
And of course, that is kind of open mapping.
It is not.
I do not want to.
Claiming that now I have done the kind of ultimate analysis and the taxonomy of post futurist design strategies so.
And of course, these these strategies partially overlap and I plan to extend them by adding more different strategies.
So this is a really open open mapping.
And.
The.

Further strategies that I considered like post post futures approaches.

Undressed stuck far who illustrated each of these.
Approaches and I'm very thankful for his contribution because my texts tend to be rather abstract and it is great when someone can transform abstract ideas into like very.
